Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: The Frequency and Patterns of Crime Against Religious Congregations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Places of worship are among the most prevalent and visible institutions in communities across the United States. This visibility, though, means that churches, synagogues, mosques, temples, and other religious congregations are often targets for street crime and ethnic- or even religiously-motivated hate crime. Indeed, it is easy to find hundreds of news reports each year about a religious congregation being victimized by vandalism, theft, arson, or some other crime. Yet, the victimization of religious congregations has received little attention by social scientists. Our research will contribute to the testing and extension of theories of crime and its relationship to community contexts, as well as theories of ethnic conflict and religious persecution.

This project will gather nationally representative survey data on the prevalence, pattern, and predictors of victimization of religious congregations along with in-depth interview data with congregational leaders and their experiences with crime. We will compare and contrast the factors that predict street crime victimization with those that predict religiously-motivated hate crime victimization. These data will not only allow social scientists to test theories of crime, ethnic conflict, and religious persecution, but they will also provide the foundation for law enforcement, community, and congregational leaders to prevent and respond to the victimization of places of worship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Places of worship are ubiquitous in neighborhoods and communities across the United States, and they represent physical symbols of religious and ethnic minority groups. This makes places of worship potentially high-risk targets of both street crime and bias-motivated hate crime. The goal of this project was to understand how places of worship think about, prepare for, and respond to being the victim of crime.

We began by conducting an analysis of newspaper records from 2012 to examine patterns of crimes against places of worship. We also examined existing data sources that provide information on religious hate crimes. We then conducted interviews with 52 places of worship representing a wide variety of religious traditions, including Protestant, Catholic, Jewish, Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, and Buddhist traditions. In these interviews we asked about the types of security measures the congregation has taken, past experiences with crime, and how the congregation reacted to those experiences.

The project has produced one peer-reviewed research article that has been accepted for publication so far. This paper is based on the analysis of newspaper records. A second paper is currently under review. This paper evaluates existing religion-related hate crime data and provides suggestions for future research.

Several papers based on our interviews with places of worship are in preparation. One of these papers examines the unique tension that religious congregations face when thinking about security measures. The mission of most places of worship is to create a feeling of sacred space. Many places of worship also want to be a place that is open and welcoming to their surrounding neighborhood. They recognize, though, that if individuals do not feel safe then this undercuts those goals. On the other hand, taking too many security measures in the form of cameras, locks, guards, or other measures also undercuts the feeling of sacredness and openness. This is a similar tension that some have perceived when discussing security at national monuments or in public buildings.

A second paper being prepared from our interview data examines the qualitative differences in the perception and experience of crime between religious majority and minority congregations. In our interviews we found examples of fairly significant vandalism, thefts, and other crimes in both Christian and non-Christian places of worship. What struck us, though, was that these incidents appeared to be experienced very differently between these categories. Christian congregations tended to view such incidents, even when severe, as nuisances. Non-Christian congregation, though, tended to be more emotionally traumatized by these events.

In addition to its research goals, the project provided research training and experiences for five undergraduate students at a teaching-focused college that rarely receives federal research awards. These students gained knowledge and experience in organizing, conducting, and disseminating research. In addition to assisting with the gathering of the project’s interview data, the students created and presented research posters based on their work with the project for the college’s undergraduate research fair.
